article_title: Medical scribes help relieve doctors’ digital record keeping
article_text:
00:59 Lock it up: Medicine safety in your home Pause

01:11 Brain-dead Vacaville toddler leaves U.S. for treatment, attorney says

02:07 Mother of toddler declared brain dead: 'I know you're going to come out of this'

00:46 "Knitted Knockers" help women with breast cancer

01:07 Music used to de-stress and calm dementia patients

01:17 Stebbins Cold Canyon Nature Reserve reopens after fire

00:43 Parents of brain dead toddler fight to keep him on life support in Roseville

01:36 California's aid-in-dying law helps one woman reclaim a 'measure of control'

01:09 Health startup incubator challenges, supports Sacramento innovators

01:04 Mentorship conference pushes black students into medical careers

article_metadata.news-keywords: medical scribes, Bob Wachter, Sutter General, UC Davis Medical Center, arthur jey
article_metadata.description: Dr. Arthur Jey shepherded a middle-aged female patient, hunched over in pain, from the Sutter General emergency waiting area to a nearby exam room – wrapping an arm around her back as he placed her gently in a chair. He knelt on the hospital floor as he examined her aching abdomen and asked about her health history. In a corner of the room, Veronica Cordero, a medical scribe, clacked at the keyboard on her mobile workstation.
article_metadata.title: Medical scribes help relieve doctors’ digital record keeping | The Sacramento Bee
